This Game Is a 10-Dollar Threat to My Personal Hygiene

Rating: 11 / 10

Alright, forget your $70 AAA disappointments. Forget buggy messes, pointless stories, and games that demand a $2,000 graphics card.

MEGABONK IS HERE. AND IT IS A BANGER.

I went in expecting a cheap laugh. I've come out 30 hours later, sleep-deprived, seeing glowing XP gems when I close my eyes, and my life has been fundamentally changed. This game has a "Very Positive" rating on Steam for a reason: it's one of the most addictive substances legally sold.

What Even Is This?

Imagine Vampire Survivors. Now, give it a 3D engine, a physics-defying jump button, a hit of 1990s-era graphics, and a truly stupid sense of humor.

You are dumped into an arena. Hordes of enemies appear. You run. You jump. You slide. And you automatically "bonk" everything in sight. You grab loot, you level up, and you create builds so absurdly overpowered that the game engine starts to sweat.

The "Just One More Run" Addiction

This game's core loop is so perfectly tuned it should be studied by scientists.

    10:00 PM: "Okay, I'll try one run. This looks silly."

    10:45 PM: "Whoa, I unlocked 'Monke' who can climb walls. And I just got an item that makes my axes orbit me. Okay, one more run to try this out."

    1:30 AM: "My build is insane. I have 70 items. I'm shooting 4,000 projectiles a second. The screen is just a solid wall of damage numbers. I am a god. I cannot be stopped."

    1:32 AM: A boss looks at me sideways. I die instantly.

    1:33 AM: "THAT WAS BULLS**T. JUST. ONE. MORE. RUN."

This is it. This is the whole game. It's perfect.

Why It's Better Than Everything Else

This game puts $100-million-dollar titles to shame.

    It Costs 10 Bucks: That's less than a single, ugly horse armor skin in Diablo. For that price, you get 20+ characters, 70+ items, and endless replayability.

    It Runs on a Toaster: The system requirements on Steam literally list "potato" for the processor and "no" for the graphics card. And it's still more fun than games that require a quantum computer.

    The Builds are STUPID (in a good way): This isn't about tiny 5% stat increases. This is about finding combinations that break the game. You can become an unkillable, screen-clearing demigod, and the game wants you to.

    No Bugs, Only Features: Unlike some games we've discussed, if you suddenly clip through the map and fly into the sky, it just feels like part of the "bonk" experience.

Conclusion:

This game is an absolute, 11/10, life-ruining masterpiece. It's pure, uncut, chaotic fun. It asks for nothing and gives you everything. Stop reading this. Go spend the 10 bucks. Go bonk.

[h1]Megabonk: The Genre-Defining 3D Bonk[/h1]

The "Survivors-like" genre is crowded, but Megabonk immediately carves out its own identity with one major, genre-defining shift: it brings the frantic chaos of reverse bullet hell into a low-poly 3D environment. This is not merely a graphical facelift; it fundamentally alters the gameplay loop. Instead of simply dodging enemies on a flat plane, players must now contend with verticality, utilizing jumps, slides, and terrain to evade or gather enormous, three-dimensional hordes. This infusion of active movement and exploration injects a kinetic energy reminiscent of games like Risk of Rain 2.

The result is a more active, strategic, and intense experience than its 2D predecessors. Adding to the freshness is the game's unapologetically chaotic and meme-heavy humor. From absurd character designs like the skating skeleton to its frantic metal soundtrack, Megabonk leans into its absurdity, ensuring the aesthetic and tone are as unique as its perspective. While the core loop of leveling up and chasing powerful builds remains addictively familiar, the full transition to 3D makes Megabonk feel less like a clone and more like a genuine evolution of the horde-survival genre. If you're looking for an auto-shooter with a genuinely new angle and tons of quirky charm, this is the bonk-tastic blast you need.

[h3] Gameplay Mechanics ‚Äì How the game plays moment-to-moment (movement, controls, unique systems). [/h3]

This is a roguelite time survival game. All you can do as the player is Walk, Crouch/Slide, Jump, Turn Camera and Aim (sometimes). It plays like Vampire Survivors or Risk Of Rain, I guess (never played it). You will enter a stage with a 10 minute countdown, and will have to go around the stage looking for chests, shrines and upgrades in general, while fighting off hoards of enemies and a few bosses. You will level up by killing enemies, allowing you to choose and upgrade your Weapons and Tomes.

this game has a silver mechanic, that is the currency that allows you to unlock new characters and gear. You gain silver passively through runs.

[h3] Difficulty & Challenge ‚Äì How hard the game is, balance of challenge, fairness. [/h3]

The game has several different levels and objectives, that make the difficulty vary a lot. To 100% it I would give it a 7, mostly due to completing 30 Challenges and a few of the weapons/tomes/item/character unlocks. In a casual run, with a meta character and build, the game can be a 5. If it were not for the tier 3 final boss, a casual run could be pretty easy, maybe a 3 or 4, But the last boss can really ruin your day.

[h3] Combat System ‚Äì How fights feel, variety of moves, enemy behavior. [/h3]

Your character uses the weapons passively, just like the items and tomes. All you gotta do is walk around and avoid being hit by enemies.

[h3] Weapons, Gear & Abilities ‚Äì Variety, upgrade systems, usefulness, uniqueness. [/h3]

The game has quite a few weapons, a lot of them are very fun to use, My favorites were the Katana, Dexecutioner, Flamewalker, Axe and Aegis.

You also have Tomes, that upgrade your stats, for example, raising your Luck, XP Gain, Damage, Attack speed, Etc.

There are also Items, that you find in chests that drop from enemies and are also bought during runs.

To unlock most of these, you need to complete some in-game challenges and sometimes buy certain items or characters and then unlock them using silver.

All unlockable items can be turned on or off, meaning you can choose not to be able to find some of them during runs, if they don't fit your build or if you want to reduce the pool size to focus on an specifc build.

[h3] Level/Area/Mob Design ‚Äì How environments are structured, exploration, layout creativity. [/h3]

There are two maps so far on the game. The Desert and the Woods.

There are 3 tiers for both of them, each connected to one another by a portal that turns on after you kill the stage boss for the tier you are on. After the tier three stage, the portal actually teleports you to a boss stage, that is the same for both Desert and Woods.

The maps themselves are ok, they are procedurally generated, so they never repeat. Each tier has a different Hue to the ambient colors, but really not different at all. The maps are unremarkable and sometimes very annoying to get around if you don't have extra jumps (Mainly woods).

I enjoy the mob design, there is quite a few different type of enemies, and some do have unique traits. For example the Desert has cacti enemies that shoot thorns at you if you sit still, so you gotta always keep moving when they spawn. However most mobs just walk at you and damage you by touching.

I kinda feel like the mobs could look a little different from one tier to another, maybe following the color scheme for each tier. For example, the tier 3 Woods has Red grass, and then maybe the mobs could be red (As they are green on tier one and also is the grass).

[h3] Story & Narrative ‚Äì Plot, characters, pacing, emotional impact. [/h3]

There is none.

[h3] Music & Sound Design - How good is the music and design and how well it fits the game. [/h3]

The music is very arcade-y, reminding me of old games that I really enjoyed as a kid. There are just a few tracks on the OST, but they more than enough for the game not to sound too repetitive. The sound design is really good, I love how satisfactory most of the sounds are. Huge bonus points for them actually adding the Bonk sound with the Bonk item haha.

[h3] Visuals & Art Style ‚Äì Graphics quality, artistic direction, animations. [/h3]

The visuals are retro, just like super nintendo, early 3D stuff. Just like Super Mario 64 and such. I think it fits the vibe of the game, and it really is quite nice to look at (at least until your super leveled weapons and skills take over the entire screen lmao.

[h3] Performance & Polish ‚Äì Bugs, frame rate, loading times, overall smoothness. [/h3]

The game runs super well 90% of the time, but I did have some freezes when opening chests and while having too many SFX from weapons going on at the same time.

[h3] Replayability ‚Äì Side content, multiple endings, NG+ options. [/h3]

The replayability is pratically infinite. There are 39 challenges, 20 characters, 29 weapons, 23 tomes and 78 items. The possibilities are practically endless, even more so with the dev updating the game quite often to change the meta sometimes.

[h3] Boss Fights ‚Äì Design, difficulty, creativity, memorability. [/h3]

Fighting bosses are just like fighting normal mobs, but with the added challenge of dodging attacks. Every tier 3 run has 3 stage bosses and 6 mini bosses. There are 6 unique mini bosses and 2 unique stage bosses. The final boss for a run is by far the hardest one. They throw annoying orbs, have invincibility phases, they disable your weapons. It is really easy to die to it even if you are op during the run. Sometimes they are a bit unfair due to where the shrines that disable the invincibility spawn, and also because of the orb behavior. There are my only issues with it (I also think it is lame that you can't lifesteal from it when it is invincible). The stage bosses and mini boses I really enjoy fighting though.

[h3] Achievements ‚Äì Creativity, difficulty, how they encourage exploration or mastery. [/h3]

The list is very complete, they make you unlock everything on the game and do 30 challenges. There are some hard unlock but there are also some easy ones, so it is a nice balance, with not much unfun grind. really solid selection. Some challenges really take some creativity to be able to get through (and some good RNG).

[h3] Conclusion 

This is a very nice roguelite, that enables the player to be engaged for hours and hours without becoming taxing. I was pretty burnout with this genre for a while and this game brought back my interest. The progression feels nice and the builds are super fun. I do wish they stole vampire survivors weapon combination idea, as Megabonk weapons could really do some crazy stuff with that mechanic. Solid 8/10 game. Best cozy game of the year.  [/h3]

[b]Megabonk[/b] is a chaotic 3D roguelite that blends humor, challenge, and frustration in equal measure. The concept is fun, gameplay is fast-paced and addicting, and the presentation has plenty of personality - yet the longevity of the game gets compromised by questionable design choices.

The first few dozen hours are easily the best part, when discovering new items and weapons still feels exciting and the difficulty curve fair. Each playable character feels distinct, and many have some kind of perk that makes their gameplay quite unique. The Forest area and its enemies are well designed, and the soundtrack does a great job of amplifying the tension and energy of each run. Unfortunately, the fun begins to fade the deeper you go, with the Desert area standing out as a frustrating mess of bad enemy types, annoying environmental hazards, and unbalanced bosses - which is a shame, since the layout itself is great.

Balance is easily Megabonk's weakest point. Weapons feel underpowered compared to items, making power progression feel inconsistent and too luck-based. The final boss fight is both unfun and mechanically dull - taking away your weapons in a game that incentivizes you to level them up is surely a weird take. Combined with issues like forced bunny hopping (the difference in mobility is night and day), many challenges and quests dragging on for too long, many weapons and tomes being massively underpowered, among other issues, it ends up feeling more like an Early Access title than a finished product.

Overall, Megabonk is a fun and unique entry in the roguelite genre that manages to have really high highs and low lows. Its early game is a blast, full of charm and chaotic fun, but it needs more work in order to have the replayability of a game like Vampire Survivors. Despite that, it's still worth checking out for its style and addicting gameplay loop.

While I've thoroughly enjoyed my time here so far, my recommendation is largely tentative and depends on my hopes for the direction that the dev will take with the game going forward. Movement is surprisingly fun, most characters are quite silly and charming, the current available maps actually feel and play very substantially different from each other and there's a pretty healthy variety of items to shake up how each run flows. Runs tend to suffer from a pretty sluggish start and endings that don't really feel totally satisfying, but everything in between feels excellent and the power curve feels solid. This sounds mostly fine and you'd expect things to smooth out with updates, but much of my concern for the future of the game comes from one particular aspect of the game that is immediately apparent the SECOND you open it.

If the inspirations weren't apparent enough from the promo material, the game can largely be described as a Risk of Rain-inspired survivor-like hybrid. While that line risks oversimplification and glossing over the details that make the game special, it should do a fine enough job of painting a picture of what to expect for those who have played those titles. Megabonk carries a number of strengths from its predecessors, but the mix of features tends to produce some new weaknesses that neither title struggled with in the past.

Items are an extremely important part of the power curve of your runs and there's a ton of them to be found. Chests are plentiful around the map and also drop from some enemies, so you'll be seeing plenty of items to platform your character. Likewise, you'll become terribly familiar with the lengthy opening cutscene the game stuffs in when interacting with any chest that slows the earlygame to an absolute crawl. The game essentially takes Risk of Rain's chests and layers the VS chest opening sequence onto them, with the result being an insane overabundance of obnoxious game-pausing menus to stare at. While the lengthy opening animation can be mostly skipped, your run is still frozen with every opening and you still have to navigate through and accept the item. It gets REALLY tedious really quickly and is one of the major factors in how slow this game feels to start.

The other big issue weighing down the earlygame at the moment is movement. As previously mentioned, I think movement in this game is surprisingly fun... Once you actually learn how to use it correctly. Most of your speed comes from a combination of item stats and funky bhopping silliness, but without one (or both) of these you are INCREDIBLY slow. Sliding down hills can help but this is largely situational and map-dependent, so if you don't know any better you're gonna be spending a lot of time casually strolling around while getting run down by enemies that either move on pace or significantly outrun you. Movement tech should serve to elevate the current experience, but at the moment it's effectively mandatory to learn due to the size and scale of the map.

But these issues can be patched. Changes can be made to improve the experience and smooth out the snail pace you're stuck with from the start. My biggest concern is what cannot be adjusted with updates, and that is the feature that is presented in the main menu as soon as the game launches: The leaderboard.

Unless hidden by a setting, there is a leaderboard that is always visible and displays the "best" runs ever performed in order of kill count. An innocent feature on its own, but with the way the game works at the moment it effectively defines a successful run by getting a lot of kills. This can only improved by two means: Grabbing difficulty-scaling items and staying alive in a run for a REALLY long time. The latter of the two is the problematic part, as every run ends with an endless survival section that exponentially scales in difficulty the longer you stay alive. The game essentially just spams one type of flying enemy at you forever and constantly increases their health and damage until you're dead. Getting smothered to death by one-tone enemy spam is a really lackluster way for a run to end, and the game railroads you into this situation at the end of literally EVERY run. 

And therein lies the problem: The leaderboard existing in its current state has effectively set this loop in stone. The current competition is very unfun, but it is what is official and thus people will compete. The loop is treated as a competitive experience and the community is giving feedback about "balance" and basing their vision on what is feasible at the "highest levels" of play... In this extremely unserious and goofy survivor-like. Will the dev make changes to the game based on the opinion of those sacrificing hours of their life running in circles for numbers that don't matter? Will nerfs come to items seen as overpowered by the smallest slice of the playerbase? Will changes be made in service to "content" the vast majority simply doesn't care about? Will good changes stay in place, even if they make things "too easy" and hurt the egos of big number gamers?

I've seen this happen a lot in other games. All we can do is see where things go from here.

- A lot of weapon types just feel unsatisfying to use.
- Weird difficulty spikes between tiers, which feel like a balance issue. 
- A lot of characters don't exist beyond their starting weapon, and there is no reason to use them.
- The geometry of the desert level feels very flat compared to the forest level. 
- Too much RNG on top of RNG. A lot of weapon and upgrade choices, but not many paths you can actually take. Makes you question why even expand your arsenal in the first place.
- Inability to exclude certain starting weapons or upgrades from being selectable. Makes me want to erase the save and just not unlock those characters/weapons.
- In the game, which is essentially about choice, interesting weapon and upgrade combinations, the final boss of each Tier 3 stage just straight up confiscates your investment. I deeply resent this design idea, and I hope it will be addressed in the future.  

Tl;dr: Amongst the abundance of games of the similar genre, Megabonk failed to meet my expectations with questionable design choices and lack of variety when it comes to meaningful upgrade paths.

Megabonk asks the question "What if you combined Risk of Rain 2 and Vampire Survivors, but removed the parts that made each of those games fun?"

I've been around the block with Survivors-likes, and I can safely say I have no idea why Megabonk of all games is getting so much attention and praise. For starters, it's missing the BIGGEST part that makes Survivors-likes so unbelievably addicting to engage with: The build variety. In Vampire Survivors, you are constantly trying to carve out your build so that it's as good as it can possibly be in the late game. Going for weapon evolutions, waiting to pick up items on the map so you can hold more than the maximum amount, shit like that. It makes every single run super engaging, since you're constantly planning for what you'll do next moment to moment. Megabonk completely lacks this mechanic, or in fact anything even remotely similar to it. You start with only 2 weapon and tome slots, and you can only get up to 4 of each, leaving you with basically no room to build out anything other than the absolute bare essentials. And I do mean "essentials", since trying to beat the game with anything other than the most obviously powerful build options will leave you completely screwed in the end due to the game's astronomical scaling. Take an Armor tome because you're out of rerolls? Unlucky. That's a completely dead tome slot, and now you can't scale your damage AT ALL because you didn't take the Damage tome. This makes the runs mind numbing and repetitive, since it's just farming for the same things over and over, and once you have your designated Good Items, you've officially made 99% of the decisions you'll make for the entire run. It's just boring compared to what I've seen elsewhere.

What about the Risk of Rain 2 elements? Those, I gotta admit, are pretty inspired. The teleporter summoning a stage boss is a neat idea, and the progression through the areas is reasonably fun. It gives you something to actually think about while you're doing a run, which is something the game desperately needed. As for the chests and the items, hooooly hell it's so unsatisfying I can't put it into words. The decision to make the chest price scale exponentially with each one you buy completely kneecaps the sensation of snowballing items that makes Risk of Rain so fun. Instead, it turns into a simulator of playing a gacha game without paying money: Spending days saving up your precious shekels until you have enough to spin the big flashy lottery machine and hope it doesn't give you a 1* oatmeal again. Utterly miserable.

The enemy design is fine, the level design is ok, and I give the game credit for being a 3D Survivors-like, something that I haven't seen before. Other than that, this game is completely redundant. It offers nothing that other games on the market can't, and I just don't understand why people have been losing their minds about it. If you want a game that's like this but better, check out Yet Another Zombie Survivors, Picayune Dreams, or even just the OG Vampire Survivors. Again, there's nothing that this game offers that those games can't deliver on in spades.
Too much time for not enough payoff.  I'd rather plan Vampire Survivors or Halls of Torment.
